primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to film form (including style and narration), different types of films, and popular approaches to the study of cinema. Topics include: narrative cinema, documentary, avant-garde, genre, authorship, ideology, and representation.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Film Study

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: • This is a fully online course. See the syllabus for more details.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course will look closely at the work of a single director. Emphasis will be given to the aesthetic, historical, cultural, and philosophical contexts that inform the director's work. We will also tend closely to the style and central preoccupations of the director under examination.[24L, 12T, 36P]
cmCourseInfo.title: Auteurs

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: Course on special topics in Cinema Studies. Topics vary each year.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Cinema Studies

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: Course on selected topics in Cinema Studies. Past topics include: "New Media."
cmCourseInfo.title: Selected Topics in Cinema Studies

sections.name: LEC0101
sections.subTitle: The Film and Video of HIV/AIDS

cmCourseInfo.description: The course may have a historical, genre, theoretical, auteur, or other focus. Students should contact the program director for the current topic. [24L, 36P]
cmCourseInfo.title: Topics in Cinema Studies
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation: (CIN101H5 or CIN202H5) or at least 1.0 credits in courses that count towards Cinema Studies programs.

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: This course focuses on queer film, television, and/or digital media. Approaches may include cultural, historical, analytical, critical, and theoretical methods. This course may focus on the representation of queer people in film in media, or film and/or media made by queer people, or both.
cmCourseInfo.title: Queer Film and Media
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: CIN105Y1, or 1.0 credit from: SDS255H1, SDS256H1, SDS279H1, SDS355H1

courses.name: Special Topics in Cinema as Social and Cultural Practice

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: Courses in special topics designed for Specialists and Majors in Cinema Studies. Past topics include: "History of Cinematography," and "Everyday Life in the Digital Age."
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Cinema as Social and Cultural Practice

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: Investigates the theory and history of media technologies as sites of aesthetic investment in a wide variety of artistic practices, focusing on contemporary digital media work, including experimental cinema, gallery installation, net.art, and avant-garde videogames. One important emphasis lies in the aesthetic possibilities new (and newly inexpensive) media technologies have made available to marginalized artists, including especially women and queer artists. We will study the work of Maya Deren, John Cage, Tony Conrad, Yoko Ono, Jack Smith, Andy Warhol, Michael Snow, Marina Abramovic, Marlon Riggs, Felix Gonzales-Torres, Anna Anthropy, and others.
cmCourseInfo.title: (New) Media Aesthetics

cmCourseInfo.description: This course offers a critical study of British film cultures, with an emphasis on British film genres, movements and cycles from the 1960s to the present day. Earlier representative works, to include the British documentary movement, will provide a foundation for a comparative study of contemporary British cinema. Major and minor film cultures will be studied in their institutional, social, and cultural contexts to include: the long standing tradition of British realism; the Free Cinema Movement; the “New Wave;” “Swinging London;” “Thatcherite” cinema, including its heritage, art cinema, Brit-grit and Black British iterations; in addition to the recent “lad boy” underclass cycle that reconfigures the traditional conceptualization of British cinema as strictly oppositional “realism or tinsel.” Debates pertinent to the way in which British films and relate to a shifting sense of national identity, towards examining the “Englishness” of British national cinema, will be highlighted. This course is offered through the Summer Abroad program.
cmCourseInfo.title: Aspects of a National Cinema

cmCourseInfo.description: Independent research projects devised by students and supervised by Cinema Studies faculty. Open to advanced Specialist and Major students in the Program. Submit applications to the Cinema Studies Undergraduate Office prior to requesting enrolment: Fall term courses, June 1/ Winter term courses, November 1/ Summer term courses, April 1. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Independent Studies in Cinema
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: At least 10.0 credits, including CIN105Y1, CIN201Y1, CIN301Y1
